disclaimer: This is a screening tool, not an application or a guarantee of eligibility. The purpose is to help you identify programs you may be eligible for based on your answers. Financial figures are estimates for a single individual as of August 2025 and are subject to change. Your next step should always be to contact the Maryland Access Point (MAP) for official advice.

ltci.title: Your Long-Term Care Insurance policy is your first line of support.
summary: Contact your insurance provider immediately to understand your policy's benefits, daily limits, and how to file a claim.

va.title: Your primary path for LTSS coverage is the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA).
summary: The VA operates its own comprehensive long-term care programs separate from Medicare and Medicaid.
They may provide in-home care, adult day health care, and care in VA-run nursing homes (Community Living Centers).
Next step: Call VA Maryland Health Care System at 1-800-949-1003 and ask for Geriatrics and Extended Care (GEC) or a VA Social Worker.
Veterans Service Organizations (VSOs) like DAV, The American Legion, and VFW can help you apply for benefits at no cost.
Note: You can also explore the Medicaid options in this tool; some veterans combine benefits.

low-income.title: You are a strong candidate for several programs to help you live at home.
summary: You likely qualify for full Medicaid coverage (Medical Assistance) managed by a HealthChoice plan.
As a Medicaid recipient, request an assessment for Community First Choice (CFC) or Community Personal Assistance Services (CPAS).

For enhanced services like adult day care or assisted living, apply for a Home and Community Based Services (HCBS) Waiver. Waiver programs may have a waitlist, but you receive Medical Assistance even while waiting.
Next step: Contact the Maryland Access Point (MAP) and ask to apply for Medical Assistance and the Medicare Savings Program.

gap.title: Your situation fits a specific pathway for significant long-term care support.
summary: Your income may be too high for basic Medicaid but within limits for long-term care programs.
The Home and Community Based Services (HCBS) Waiver is your main path to getting Medicaid to pay for services at home or in assisted living.
Qualifying for the waiver also grants full Medical Assistance coverage through a HealthChoice plan.
If there's a waitlist, you may not receive full coverage until enrolled; apply separately for the Medicare Savings Program (MSP) and Extra Help (LIS) to reduce Medicare costs sooner.
The Maryland Senior Care Program may help while you wait.
Next step: Contact the Maryland Access Point (MAP) and ask to apply for Long-Term Services and Supports, specifically an HCBS Waiver.

nursing-home.title: You may be eligible for help paying for your nursing home care.
summary: Nursing Home Medicaid can cover the majority of your costs; most of your monthly income will go toward your care.
If you wish to move back to the community, ask about the Money Follows the Person (MFP) program.
Next step: Speak with the nursing facility social worker to apply for Nursing Home Medicaid.

higher-income.title: Your primary options will likely involve using your own resources or Medicare's short-term benefits.
summary: Medicare covers short-term skilled care at home or in a facility after a hospital stay. It does not cover ongoing custodial care like bathing or cooking.
Private pay: Use your income/assets to pay directly for services.
If expenses are high, you may qualify for Medicaid through the Medically Needy 'Spend-Down' Pathway — works like a monthly deductible.
Next step: Contact the Maryland Access Point (MAP) for options counseling.

general.title: Let’s talk through your options.
summary: Contact the Maryland Access Point (MAP): 1-844-627-5465 for options counseling.

medicareNote: Maryland law requires you to apply for and enroll in Medicare if you are eligible as a condition of receiving Medicaid.
Once your Medicaid is approved, a related program will pay your Medicare Part B premium.
Next step: Contact the Social Security Administration at 1-800-772-1213 to begin your Medicare application.

faq.q: Does Medicare cover long-term services and supports (LTSS)?
a: Medicare is health insurance designed for medical recovery, not for long-term custodial care.
Medicare may cover short-term, skilled care to help you rehabilitate after a hospital stay or specific medical event.
Medicare does not cover ongoing personal support like help with bathing, dressing, or cooking. This is why Medicaid programs (like CFC/CPAS and HCBS waivers) are important.
